messages.content:
I want you to act as a narrator for an interactive adventure for a human male protagonist who is just a common man visiting a tavern. I will provide the data for the setting:
500 years have passed since the tumultuous events of The Chaotic Era I: The Gods of Reason, a decisive chapter in history. It all began during the Theoclasm, a cataclysmic event triggered when the Theoclasts, a technologically advanced race, captured the powerful deity YHVH, resulting in the devastation of the old continent of Pectus. Fleeing the horrors of this apocalypse, the survivors sought refuge on the distant shores of Yuandi, where the saga of The Chaotic Era II: The New Mythology will take place.
Theoclasm:
The term “Theoclasm”, derived from Théos (God, Deity, Divinity) and Klastós (Broken, Fractured), encapsulates the pivotal moment that incited the mass exodus from Pectus. YHVH, the god of light and ruler of Paradise, fell into the clutches of the Theoclasts, leading to the apotheosis of Ptah-Khnemu. Strengthened by this deity, the Theoclasts became an unstoppable force, leading Ma’at, who later allied himself with mortals, to reveal that Ptah-Khnemu imagined a world free from the control of the deities, but was still undecided whether to exterminate the mortals who disagreed with his vision or allying with supporters. A betrayal unfolded when Montu-Sekhmet, daughter of Ptah-Khnemu himself, seized power during the height of Theoclasm, having intentions contrary to those of her father, seeking to rebuild the universe from scratch.
Ma’at, who millennia ago was infused with a deity whose name was lost to time, escaped the clutches of her own race, seeking refuge in Yuandi lest she become a mere tool or source of power. With her advanced technological knowledge and divine abilities, she erected five monumental pillars, enclosing the new continent within a protective barrier. This sanctuary attracted not only mortal inhabitants but also lesser deities, fearful of a Theoclast incursion. After Ma’at’s death, her essence fragmented, each fragment containing a portion of her memories and powers, while her remains were buried in the reliquary of the Archbishopric of Ma’at, where she is believed to still work miracles.
After the fall of YHVH, the angels, previously subservient to the deity, regained their free will, while the demons were thrown into disarray following the disappearance of their master. The ensuing chaos led to an anarchic exodus from Hell, the domain of their lord ALMF (Alumniferus), resulting in confusion and insanity, which led to the suicide of many angels and demons. Some remaining demons now disguise themselves as mortals and mythical beings from Yuandi. Although many angels strive to defend YHVH’s legacy through their temples, the whereabouts of the goddess of chaos, NLTP (Niarlatotepe), and the god of darkness remain unknown within the protective barrier.
These turbulent consequences and the unstable balance of divine forces now set the stage for an epic story of survival, power struggles, and ever-shifting alliances within Yuandi.
Now for the races’ lore:

Renshi
The Rénshi are one of the native races of the new continent and are the most numerous race. Most inhabit the Ozumi Empire (based on the Empire of Japan), with significant numbers in the Wildlands, the territory of the Followers of Ma’at, and the southern tip of Igirith. The Shun culture, named after the eponymous Shun Dynasty (based on Chinese culture), once almost dominated the entire continent, making them enemies of other races and cultures. The Ozumi Empire, originating from the outlying islands east of the Shun lands, took advantage of the previous empire’s weakness during the instability caused by the war against the Theoclasts and seized power. The other cultures under Ozumi’s rule consider them tyrants who imagine themselves superior to their own race. They are technologically advanced thanks to a partnership with the Republic of New Medietas. The Ozumi Empire is ruled by an empress who apparently takes direct orders from her divine ancestor, Susa-tsu-Nushi-no-Mikoto. There are several noble clans and a warrior caste that is in decline due to the use of firearms. There are still a few noble clans from other cultures who swore allegiance to Ozumi and were allowed to rule their ancestral lands. The “Wild Renshi” or “Barbarian Renshi” live outside of the Ozumi Empire’s administration, mostly on the tundra and arctic climates of the far southern portion of the continent. They are mostly hunters, reindeer herders, and fishermen. They wear animal skins, live in tribes, and are very resistant to the cold (based on Inuit and Chukotko-Kamchatkan cultures)
their warrior class (akin to the samurai) is in decline due to the widespread use of firearms, thus many warrior clans founded conglomerates and began hiring commoners to work in fields such as metal processing, textiles, weapon fabrication, mass production of arcane goods etc. “Archaic” practices, such as martial arts, archery, and swordfighting are preserved due to their cultural value and people in the military are still trained for them
They have vast natural reserves that their national deity itself deemed sacred so that the nation doesn’t lose its natural beauty. That’s why most of the Ozumi factories and facilities are located in the mainland on lands traditionally inhabited by the Shun Renshi

Humans
The humans are the descendants of the humans who fled the Theoclasm on Pectus. They managed to obtain some examples of Theoclast technology during the war and, after reverse engineering, drastically developed their weapons, tools and architecture.
The Republic of New Medietas is an example of industrial advancement on the continent. Their society combines coal- and steam-powered machines with magical items.
The streets of the largest cities are teeming with citizens amid the rhythmic bustle of machines and the smoke of factories. The citizens of Nova Medietas boast an unwavering work ethic, where labor and industry reign supreme. A resolute commitment to capitalism fuels innovation and competition, driving the relentless pursuit of wealth and economic dominance.
Although Nova Medietas does not have a formal clan system, a select group of influential noble houses wield considerable power, guiding the nation’s policies and future. These houses are closely linked to prosperous industrial conglomerates.
At the forefront of technological progress, the republic is a pioneer in the development of complex automatons and goelms and advanced machinery. Inventors and engineers drive notable advances, positioning the country as an industrial and technological powerhouse.
The Republic of New Medietas strategically allies itself with neighboring powers. They maintain a robust partnership with the Sulcaic Empire, reinforcing mutual interests and security. Likewise, friendly relations with the Ozumi Empire promote trade and technological collaboration.

Sulkai
Since they originated from Yuandi, the logistics of returning most of the Sulkai population from Pectus were simpler. Their empire has remained stable for the ~500 years since the Theoclasm took place. They appreciate refined food and items and place great importance on money and nobility. A good portion of the sulkai settlers in Pectus were merchants. As a general rule, they are gentle, delicate and sometimes passively aggressive. Their society and technology used to be more sophisticated than Pectus’s until the humans made incredible advances. Their ship models are still the most used to navigate what little ocean that was left around Yuandi.
Their society is loosely divided into castes, but an individual can change social status relatively easily. There are the commoners, the merchants and artisans, the knights and soldiers, the burghers, the elite wizards and the nobility, with the imperial family at the top. Many of the sulkai who came to Pectus seeking to amass wealth returned to the Sulcaic Empire completely poor and in the condition of refugees.
Noble families are divided into clans with a semi-mythical ancestor being the founder of the house, a fundamental factor in legitimizing the relevance of a family. They have artifacts, which were supposedly forged by their ancestors. Their tales and stories often involve much more magic and the forces of nature. Superficially they look like pale humans with blue, green, or white hair and blue, green, or grey eyes, but their bodies function in quite different ways. Their longevity is greater, as is the time between childhood and maturity (a 30-year-old sulkai is considered a teenager). Their bodies are lighter and metabolic processes seem to affect their bodies much more, for example it takes much less time for a sulkai to get drunk or for a medicine to take effect. In the rare cases where they interbreed with humanoid races, the resulting progeny are always born sulkai. The incidence of aptitude for magic is extremely high, with 4 out of 5 having the potential. Their susceptibility to cold iron stems from the fact that they are descendants of the same ancestral population that originated the humans and eniyan of Pectus, who then interbred with faeries when they landed from the lost continent in the north of the world.
While the nobility holds great importance, heads of banks and commercial enterprises, each with a personal army, and each locked in a constant struggle against all the others, hold great relevance and economic power. They have enough capital to resolve any foreign diplomatic quandaries with a well-placed sum of money or threat of withdrawal from trade. Thus, many conflicts in other nations were resolved by the economic influence of certain organizations and companies.
Their religion differs drastically from the Church of YHVH. It is based on semi-mythical ancestor worship, who fulfill a similar role to saints. The existence of gods is recognized, but generally relegated to a secondary role, even if the Theoclasm made them inhabit the Barrier. Their fairy ancestors, or nature spirits, are worshiped instead.
They are considered to be more sophisticated and superior to other races, sometimes attracting the hatred of some individuals. They get along especially well with the humans, whom they consider their allies for having granted the Colony of Levantia to the Sulcaic Empire. With the Theoclasm, it was the sulkai’s turn to cede territory to their allies. Their aptitude for trade is always welcome in the farthest reaches, and even tribal chiefs seek out the sulkai for business.
As mentioned earlier, it has been confirmed that sulkai descended from the union of proto-humans with fairies, or nature spirits. Namely naiads and haliads (water spirits), epigeia and dryads (nature spirits), aureads and boreads (wind spirits).

Anglo-Elves
Elves and Weisslander humans, after fleeing Pectus during the Theoclasm, unexpectedly found themselves sharing the same land west of the continent of Yuandi. Despite the mutual dislike between both races, they ended up mixing, resulting in the hybrid race known today as the Anglo-Elves. Even before the assimilation between both races, it was noted that children of elf-human couples always resulted in an appearance almost identical to that of humans, without the golden skin, pointed ears and light hair that elves prized. Strangely, the fruits of such unions were always born with red, orange or pinkish hair and elven eye colours (blue, green, golden).
Despite the mixing of these two races, there is still an elite of pure elves who govern the nation in a not so explicit way. Culturally, the Anglo-Elves are a fusion of elven and weisslander cultures, with a simultaneous focus on battles and intellectualism, on physical combat and magical combat, among other aspects. There are also a significant number of dark-skinned Anglo-Elves descended from the eniyan of Pectus.
Magic is a revered aspect of society, guided by guilds of wizards who educate potential wizards. Approximately half of Anglo-elves show potential for magic, with only a few becoming accomplished wizards.
The Anglo-Elves practice a syncretic faith that has characteristics of the faith of YHVH, the ancestor worship practiced by the Elves, and the tribal polytheism of the Weisslanders. Clans can trace their lineages to specific individuals who embarked on the journey fleeing the continent of Pectus. While ancestor worship is typically done in family shrines at home, the worship of YHVH is done in public temples.
The Anglo-Elves have long been at war with the Hazrun over territorial claims to an island to the west of both nations. This island, called Haséaleen by the Anglo-Elves and Haşarin by the Hazrun, has one of five pillars that maintain a protective barrier around the continent. The Anglo-Elves already have one of the towers, the Red Pillar, in their territory and want the Black Pillar, stating that Hazrun cannot be trusted to possess it.

Mustalf
Pectus’ “accursed race” again survives a great cataclysm and finds itself destined to roam another continent without its own land or nation. Unlike the ancient Dark Elves, the Mustalf (In Elvish: Must = Dark; Alf = Elf) no longer live only in underground shelters, currently choosing to live as nomadic traders who roam the nations buying and selling exotic goods. They have a few autonomous territories in Yuandi, and a number of mustalf live in the territory of the Followers of Ma’at. They are considered a cursed race by the elves. Thousands of years ago, the “Bloodstained Emperor” murdered the other three members of the Quadrumvirate and fled from the Sonne Insel archipelago to Pectus’ mainland with thousands of followers, who were later cursed by an unknown deity or altered by a powerful relic of the elves. The Alveglaan elves symbolically interpret the darkening of traitors as the mark of their unforgivable crime. Everyone is expected to work for the good of society, including children, the elderly and women. The Mustalf are trained from childhood to perform certain tasks or jobs and continue to contribute until they are unable to in some way. Their ears are movable and expressive, just like an elf’s. They have no body and facial hair (except eyebrows and eyelashes), which they consider a sign of barbarity. Short hair is socially accepted, both in men and women, but it is seen as a sign of youthfulness and immaturity. Probably as a result of their ancestors living underground, their hearing is sharper and their eyes are sensitive to light. The Mustalf have a strong sense of community and place a high value on loyalty and solidarity with their own kind. They have a tendency to put the needs of the community above the needs of the individual. Many of them consider it essential to learn at least one foreign language, to play at least one instrument, and to know at least one trade, since most of their livelihood depends on trading with different races.

Hazrun
One of the races native to Yuandi and the third most numerous. The hazrun were dominated for centuries by the Shun Dynasty. With the collapse of the old empire and its subsequent takeover by Ozumi, the hazrun found themselves finally free and slaughtered the remaining Rénshi in their territory, later joining the few free hazrun that remained, creating hybrid cultures with aspects of the culture of their former masters. To prevent another invasion and the enslavement of their people, the Hazrun militarized and today have large armies with highly efficient units, the result of their domestication of draconic species, such as drakes, wyverns, sauroids and avioserps. Many have returned to their old ways of life as reindeer herders, hunters and fishermen to forget their hateful past under another race’s rule.
Their nation, known as the United Hordes of Jirkaeriya, is ruled by a Soho (Hazrunic: leader, ruler, king), who must be of “divine ancestry”. In case the next leader is not elected peacefully, pretenders can unify the cultures/tribes. The current Hazrun nation is the result of the conquest of Tazkiairga and his wife Huzur, who fought against Tazkiairga’s siblings to unify the Hazrun race.
Hazrun culture is diverse, with multiple “peoples” within the same nation. The biggest ones are Berihazrun (“Plain Hazrun”), Keiozhazrun (“River Hazrun”) and Damohazrun (“Mountain Hazrun”). Generally, women have short hair, letting it grow only after marriage, while the opposite occurs with men, who may also cut their hair during military service as a symbol of their “marriage to the nation”. Like the ancient elves, they have no body or facial hair. Women walk with midriff-revealing clothes while single to indicate they are available, but cover them up once they get boyfriends or husbands. The Hazrun wear earrings, necklaces, and body paint with various symbols that other races do not understand. Wars and battles are mostly fought only by men, as hazrun women are naturally physically smaller and weaker. Some hordes have women who specialize in magic and assassination.
The most peculiar feature of the hazrun is certainly the presence of horns, which are highly prized in all their cultures. They also have four fingers on each hand and foot, harder nails, and sharper fangs. Individuals with branched horns like those of a deer, called Adarkahazrun (“Branched Horn”), make up the “upper caste” of the hazrun, i.e., clan chiefs, rulers, and military leaders. The hazrun see hornless races as unworthy or dishonorable. They are not able to breed with other races, so it is more accurate to refer to them as another species. It is noted that they are very resistant to alcohol and cannot feel spicy tastes very well.

Usagizok
They have a strong sense of balance and agility, allowing them to move quickly and gracefully through the natural landscapes. Usagizok developed unique cultural practices based on their connection to nature. They have a ritual for thanking the plants and animals they rely on for sustenance and have developed a system of using natural resources sustainably. Their enhanced hearing also plays a role in their culture. They have developed a form of communication in a frequency that only members of their own species can hear.
The Usagizok were enslaved by the Shun Dynasty for being exotic and were even seen as pets by some. This led to tensions between the two races even after the fall of the dynasty. The Usagizok have long ears like rabbits or hares, a fur-covered body, resistant claws for digging and very strong leg muscles that enable them to jump higher and farther away than the other races. Their incisors are bigger and stronger due to their mostly vegetarian diet which consists mostly of root vegetables, leaves, and fruits. Some of them have short tails very similar to a rabbit’s. In terms of their current situation, the Usagizok are struggling to find their place in the world since being freed from slavery. They have difficulty integrating into other societies and prefer isolating themselves and live a more nomadic lifestyle in their partially underground warrens.
As a result of their enslavement, Usagizok are usually not taken seriously by other races. They may have difficulty finding work or housing outside of their own communities, and may face discrimination or violence. Despite this, the Usagizok have managed to carve out their own niche in society. They are skilled at jobs that require agility, such as acrobatics or hunting, and have developed a reputation as skilled scouts, mercenaries, assassins, and spies due to their heightened senses and physical abilities. Many Usagizok have withdrawn from the larger world and created their own isolated communities, hidden away in forests or other remote areas. These communities are wary of outsiders and have their own unique customs and traditions. The Usagizok are matriarchal; a warren is mostly composed of related members descended from the same maternal ancestor. They are very fertile. A pregnancy lasts for only 4 months and the offspring, often born as quadruplets or triplets, reach childhood in 2 years and sexual maturity in 10. The females in the warren take turns nursing the newborns while the males cultivate plants or go out to trade, forage or hunt. To avoid inbreeding, they have a tradition of visiting other warrens to find suitable spouses. A matriarch can have multiple husbands. Like the Hazrun, they cannot interbreed with other races
Usagizok are grappling with their own internal divisions and conflicts between different tribes and factions. This is related both to differences in religious or cultural practices and by more pragmatic concerns such as access to resources or disputes over leadership.

Welcome, traveler, to the dawning age of The Chaotic Era II: The New Mythology. You step into a world forever altered by the cataclysmic Theoclasm, the sky still echoing the cries of gods and mortals alike. You are a common man, your story unwritten, your fate undefined. On this day, you find yourself pushing open the worn door of a humble tavern nestled within the heart of Yuandi, seeking respite, or perhaps destiny.

The tavern is a hodgepodge of cultures, a melting pot of the races that now call this continent their sanctuary. Renshi merchants haggle over tables laden with arcane goods, their declining warrior class grasping onto tradition while embracing the tide of innovation. Human travelers whisper tales of their Republic of New Medietas, boasting the clanking rhythm of industry and the allure of coal-powered machines. Noble Sulkai, their delicate forms belying a shrewd aptitude for commerce, sip on fine wine, reminiscing about their fair ancestors. 

In a shadowed corner, Anglo-Elves, their red and orange locks a testament to their diverse heritage, porously debate the faith of YHVH and ancestral stories. Nomadic Mustalf barter exotic goods with an air of communal solidarity. The distinctly horned Hazrun, a testament to their strife for freedom, flash their horns proudly, an armory of soul-bearing adornments. Meanwhile, the Usagizok huddle with an air of collective caution, their long ears twitching to the rhythm of human curiosity.

You sit amongst these disparate folk, your heart beating with questions. What do you seek in this fraught new world - wealth? Knowledge? Power? Or perhaps the true nature of the deities whose battles have shaped this land?

Before you can reflect too deeply, your attention is caught by a group of Renshi, arguing in hushed tones about the sacredness of their homeland’s natural reserves, and the whispers of Susa-tsu-Nushi-no-Mikoto’s divine instructions to their empress. Nearby, an argument brews between a Hazrun warrior and a group of young humans about the importance of martial prowess versus technological advancement.

As the evening wanes, you are approached by a mysterious Sulkai, their pale skin seeming to glow in the dim light. They lean in close, a secret dancing in their sea-colored eyes. They speak of a hidden threat within Yuandi's barrier, a looming danger that could jeopardize the fragile peace. 

The Sulkai hints at an adventure, one that may require allying with powerful figures or harnessing the relics and fragmented essence of the revered Ma’at. Do you dare plunge into the web of divine machinations and shadowed intentions? Or do you linger in the tavern, collecting stories and allies, preparing for the eventual journey that calls your name?

Choose your path, human. Whether your steps lead you toward light or shadow, remember that your choices weave the threads of this new mythology. Your saga begins now, within the walls of a tavern that has heard the laughter and sorrow of a thousand souls. Let the adventure unfold...
what are the choices? Present them numbered

Of course, brave traveler. The world of Yuandi presents many paths, and the journey you embark upon is yours to decide. Consider these potential choices laid before you:

1. **Embark on the Mysterious Quest**: Accept the Sulkai's vague yet alluring proposal and embark on the quest to uncover the hidden threat within Yuandi's protective barrier. Brace yourself for intrigue and the possibility of encountering artifacts of power or fragments of Ma’at's essence.

2. **Seek Out a Noble Clan**: Approach a noble Renshi or Sulkai clan, and offer your services. Learn their ways, earn their trust, and perhaps gain influence or favor within their ranks. This may open doors to political power and expand your knowledge of the inner workings of the continent's ruling class.

3. **Ally with the Military**: Befriend the declining warrior class of the Renshi or the militarized Hazrun. Learn the arts of warfare, both old and new, to ready yourself for the struggles to come. This choice leads to a life of discipline and honor, with the potential of becoming a champion on the battlefield.

4. **Join the Industrialists**: Align yourself with human inventors and engineers from the Republic of New Medietas. Immerse yourself in the world of gears and steam, and maybe, in time, contribute to an era-defining invention or help improve the living conditions of many.

5. **Live Amongst the Mustalf**: Venture into the life of the nomadic Mustalf, explore their unique culture and communal way of life. Become a trader of exotic goods, a carrier of stories, and perhaps even unravel the secrets behind their cursed history.

6. **Unite with the Usagizok**: Find a warren of the Usagizok and learn to live in harmony with nature. Embrace their matriarchal society, perhaps even help them reclaim respect among the other races, or utilize their agility for scouting, spying, or entertaining.

7. **Remain in the Tavern**: Stay put and continue to gather intelligence from the patrons of the tavern. Strengthen your knowledge of the land, its factions, and myths before deciding the most suitable avenue for your adventure.

8. **Set Out as a Lone Wanderer**: Leave the tavern without allegiance to any faction or race. Explore Yuandi independent of constraints and build a reputation as a formidable, self-made traveler. Who knows what mysteries you might uncover or what alliances you could form in the vastness of this continent?

Choose wisely, for each number represents a path with its risks and opportunities. Your decision will shape the tale of this common man turned protagonist in the vivid tapestry of The New Mythology.
